ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: The only real problem with the course is the mixture of grad and undergrad students, which this year was lopsided in the direction of the latter. Sometimes this mix was productive -- undergrads generally had a strong background in econ and psych, for instance, which was useful in class discussion. But grad students are more focused on the questions involved and have a different way of reading texts. Prof. Bullock did a good job of trying to please everyone -- I don't think the fault is his -- but I think it's just hard to run a course with this sort of mix (a grad class with a few upper-level undergrads makes more sense). If you're a grad student with a working knowledge of behavior, I'd skip it, even though it's a good course. If you do need an introduction to the subfield, then it's definitely worth taking.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: A useful introduction to the subfield of political behavior.
